title: Disables ProGuard optimizations in Statistics
message:
Disables ProGuard optimizations in Statistics

Apparently I've been not properly saving my statistics since I started
using ProGuard in may. ProGuard optimizes the names for the fields in
Statistics classes so that instead of "color", "total", "sizes" the
fields are renamed to "a", "b" and "c". Unfortunately, that also affects
the generated JSON through serialization and reflection. And,
unfortunatelly as well, I'm hardcoding the expected strings to read as
the non-optimized values. Therefore, they are never properly read
because the JSON contains an "a" where my logic expects a "color".

Apply this commit to backport the routines related to Google Play

adds support for Google Play Games and reporting scores and other events

title: Add Share button to statistics
message:
Add Share button to statistics

The user can share screenshots of the Statistics screen by pressing
the Share button, now located at the Statistics button. The screenshot
is resized to match the size of the widget, so no scroll bars are
visible.

Screenshot is taking by generating a Frame Buffer Object and rendering
the contents of the table widget to that Frame Buffer Object, then
converting the FBO to a Pixmap and then saving the pixmap via the
standard Sharing system.

This means that on desktop the user will see the Save as... window,
while on Android an Intent for sharing the photo will be triggered
letting the user share the screenshot via other apps.

Closes #50.

title: Save state on Android Bundles
message:
Save state on Android Bundles

Introduce the concept of savedState. Android allows you to save the
state of an activity so that if the activity is destroyed because
of the system needing that resources, it can then recreate the
activity.

This is NOT a persistent save, it's just a temporal save in case the
activity is destroyed because of low resources, and it's exactly
what I need to avoid losing Rectball state in case the player
minimizes the game for such a long time that the system kills the
game.

What this change introduces is the packing of all the state-related
variables into the GameState variable. Then, a system is provided
for storing that GameState into a serialized string when the state
has to be saved.

In case Android kills the activity, the onCreate method will
re-create the activity with all the previous state and the game will
continue thanks to the changes introduced in the GameScreen that check

* The board should be grayed out while the game is on pause to
  avoid cheats. When the user clicks again in the window and the
  game resumes, the board is coloured again.

* If the user pauses the game before the countdown ends, the game
  is not supposed to begin. The very second the game resumes after
  that, the game starts.

* If the user backs before the countdown ends, the game is not
  supposed to begin. The very second the user cancels after that,
  the game starts.

Instead of composing the layout on load() method, now the layout

This has been done because some screens have to change the information

on show().

Now, every time the screen is displayed, the layout can be created
with the new values for the screen.
